Generating synthetic data using AI

ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

Capstone project of the data science Bootcamp, Zurich, 2022. The project was proposed by the SIX group.

Companies nowadays handle large amounts of data and use it for many types of statistical analysis. In most cases, this data contains the personal information of many users. A solution to this problem is to generate synthetic data, i.e., data preserving the statistical properties of the real data, yet fake.

In this project, we generated synthetic data using two well-known algorithms in the field of deep learning: Generative Adversarial Networks and Variational Autoencoders. We also used not-so-known variations of these algorithms. Our conclusions agree with the current research. There is a trade-off between the usability and the privacy of the synthetic data.

Check our project in Github

Gravitational lensing and galaxy cluster mass density profile

ASTRONOMY

Research collaboration with the Astrophysics Department of the University of Oviedo, 2020-2021. Remote.

Gravitational lensing is the effect of light distortion provoked by a gravitational force between the light source and the observer.

Positive Hopf plumbed links with maximal signature

MATHEMATICS

This is the topic of my doctoral thesis, University of Bern, Bern, 2017-2021.

Think of a knot as a closed curve embedded in the 3d space. Just as if you could join the two tips of your shoelace, that would be the mathematical idea of a knot. And a link is the extension to many closed curves, the simplest link is what we call a Hopf link: . In addition, if we give an orientation to the curves, we can distinguis between two tipes of Hopf links: positive and its mirror the negative Hopf link.

Two knots are equivalent when you can transform one knot into another without the need of "cutting". You can check the video for an example.

"What is knot theory about? One answer is that knot theory studies the placement problem: Given spaces X and Y, classify how X may be placed within Y."--Louis H. Kauffman. In the example above, the space X is a closed curve, and the space Y is the 3d space, that leads to the classical idea of a knot.

It is possible to create more complex links and knots by "joining" Hopf links, and by "joining" I refer to an operation called plumbing. Just as if the hopf link was a lego piece, one can create very complicated constructions. In this case, however, the resulting link may be isotopic to a very simple one, just like in the video. In my thesis, I consider those links constructed by "joining" positive Hopf links. And prove that, when they satisfy a certain property (maximal signature), then they are equivalent to a set of "canonical" links.

Link to my Thesis

Transformation from a rather complicated knot to a trefoil knot. Animation created with KnotPlot.

Jordan decomposition of the Kronecker product of two Jordan matrices

MATHEMATICS

Undergraduate research, Wayne State University, Detroit, 2013-2014.

A Jordan block is a square matrix of size \(n\) with \(\lambda\) in the diagonal, ones in the superdiagonal, and zeroes elsewhere, denoted by \(J_{n}(\lambda)\). A Jordan matrix is a diagonal matrix, where the diagonal is composed of Jordan blocks, usually denoted as \(J_{n_{1}}(\lambda_{1})\oplus\dots\oplus J_{n_{r}}(\lambda_{r})\).

We showed that the Kronecker product \(J_{2}(\lambda) \otimes J_{n}(\mu)\) is congruent to \(J_{n-1}(\lambda\mu)\oplus J_{n+1}(\lambda\mu)\) for characteristic different from two, and \(J_{n}(\lambda\mu)\oplus J_{n}(\lambda\mu)\) for characteristic equal to two. What about \(J_{3}(\lambda)\otimes J_{n}(\mu)\)? And for \(J_{m}(\lambda) \otimes J_{n}(\mu)\)?

More about Jordan matrices
More about Kronecker product



An example of a Jordan matrix composed by two Jordan blocks with diagonals \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\) and sizes 4 and 3, respectively.
